Subject: NEAT Hopper and Writing Your Own NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

I was looking at Mattias Fagerlund's most recent NEAT Hopper demo, and
I thought it was worth mentioning a few things about it here for
people who are currently trying to create their own NEAT systems, or
new to working with NEAT.  The demo is available here and runs in
Windows:

http://www.cambrianlabs.com/Mattias/Evolved/NEATHopper.asp

The reason I bring this program up is it is an excellent demonstration
of how NEAT works, and how it should work.  It also has a lot of great
interface and visualization ideas.  I believe it would be helpful to
play with for anyone newly working with NEAT.

I suggest running it first with only the following options checked:
-Only draw better (only shows you when a champ improves)
-Real-time draw  (draws at a real-world frame rate)
-Joint limits  (doesnt let piece of the hopper move through each
other)
-Foot trace (shows the path it took)
-Shadows (look nice)

To speed things up, I would also uncheck "multi-run," which doesn't
seem necessary.  (The program starts with this option checked by
default)

The "Forward Distance" fitness measure is probably the best for
demonstration purposes, but I also found "Standtime" interesting,
where
the hopper learns to balance without falling.

The thing that is very useful to watch in this demo is how the
networks complexify as the hopper learns to get farther and farther
down the track.  You can actually watch the complexification by
choosing the "Champview" tab in the stats window.  I suggest sitting
down for a good  150 generations (which only takes a few minutes) and
watching how complexification contributes to function.  (Note that
sometimes the champ becomes simpler, not because NEAT simplified the
network, but because a simpler species outpaced a more complex one,
since NEAT keeps lots of different complexities in the population!)

The other useful thing is the "fitness spread" tab, which shows the
fitness of the entire population, color-coded by species.  So if you
keep this tab on, you can see species growing and shrinking over time
depending how good they are, and also you can see new species coming
in, and how sometimes a new species immediately introduces something
good, and sometimes an old species keeps gradually improving.  It
really gives you a sense of how fitness sharing should work.
(Though I don't know if Mattias used a dynamic speciation threshold,
which may improve things even more)

I really think that this demo can help beginners to understand NEAT in
a way that verbal explanations cannot, so I hope people take an
opporunity to check it out.

ken
